awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for Real World Cryptography 2020 (RWC '20)
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal partially supports 26 students for their travel to attend the 2020 Real World Cryptography Conference (RWC) to be held in New York, NY, USA from Jan. 8-10, 2020. RWC has emerged as a premier venue for the presentation of ideas, advances and challenges from both academic and industrial cryptographers and security researchers. The conference aims to bring better understanding of real-world cryptographic issues to the theoretical community, helping to inform their research and set new research challenges for the theoretical community, and enables practitioners to develop a clearer view of the current state-of-the-art in cryptographic research and what it offers to practice. The organizers will prioritize student speakers, students from underrepresented groups, and students from universities where research funds are not available. As such, it fits closely with the goals of NSF's Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, which include applied cryptography and implementation of cryptographic schemes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Real World Cryptography series of conferences was born in 2012 from a workshop entitled “Is Theoretical Cryptography Practically Relevant?”, held at Cambridge University as part of the 2012 Alan Turing year. The goals of that workshop were:


1) To bring a better understanding of real-world cryptographic issues to the theoretical community, helping to inform their research and set new research challenges


2) To enable practitioners to develop a clearer view of the current state-of-the-art in cryptographic research and what it offers to practice


3) To provide a forum for exchanging ideas and building relationships between researchers from the different communities


and these remain the basic goals of the RWC series. The 2012 event was attended by approximately 100 people.  RWC 2020 had an audience of nearly 700 people.  RWC 2021 was held remotely due to the pandemic, and RWC 2022 was held in hybrid format with nearly 500 in-person registrations and 250 remote registrations.


Intellectual Merit: RWC has emerged as a premier venue for the presentation of ideas, advances and challenges from both academic and industrial cryptographers and security researchers. The yearly attendance significantly surpass that of other top-tier events in cryptography, e.g., CRYPTO and EUROCRYPT.


Broader Impacts: This student travel grant provided funding for 21 students from US institutions to attend the Real World Cryptography 2020 conference held in January 2020 New York City, including 10 women, and funding for an additional three students (including two women) from US institutions to attend the Real World Cryptography 2022 conference in person in Amsterdam in April 2022.


The students were exposed to talks about the state of the art in both academic and industrial research; they had ample opportunities to network with student colleagues, potential employers (both for internships and post-graduation jobs) and post-doctoral advisors. In addition to the talks, RWC specifically has a mid-event "lightning talk" session, in which employers have a few minutes to introduce their company/institution and talk about openings that they need to fill.  (There were roughly 50 such announcements during the session.)  This makes students aware of who they should chat up in the "hallway track" or contact after the event, as well as more generally informing them of the vast number of excellent positions available.


Last Modified: 07/08/2022
Modified by: Nadia Heninger
